analysisNotes: for any perseus question that requires interaction fromthe user. we should never request an input box. we should create 4 widgets for every choice (multiple choice) with one showing the correct line of reflection

hints.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[â˜ƒ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[â˜ƒ definition 2]], but on the other side.



[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

This means that the line of reflection is the line that contains the midpoints between corresponding points of the pre-image and image.

options.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

options.definition: The figure *after* one or more transformations

hints.content:
We could pick any pairs of corresponding points to help us find the line of reflection. 

First, let's find the midpoint between $\blueD{B(5,5)}$ and $\maroonD{B'(1,5)}$.

$\left( \dfrac{\blueD{5}+\maroonD{1}}{2}, \dfrac{\blueD{5}+\maroonD{5}}{2}\right)=(3,5)$



[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle ABC and triangle A prime B prime C prime are drawn. Triangle ABC has point A at seven, six, point B at five, five, and point C at four, three. Triangle A prime, B prime, C prime has point A prime at negative one, six, point B prime at one, five, point C prime at two, three. There is a plotted point at three, five at the endpoint of one line segment connected to B and another line segment connected to B prime. These line segments are congruent.

hints.content:
We can see that the corresponding points would connect with a *horizontal* line segment. The line of reflection is perpendicular to that segment, so the line of reflection must be the *vertical* line that passes through $(3,5)$.

Alternatively, we can find the midpoint of another pair of corresponding points. For example, the midpoint of $\blueD{C(4,3)}$ and $\maroonD{C'(2,3)}$ is $(3,3)$, so the line of reflection passes through $(3,5)$ and $(3,3)$.

The line $x=3$ reflects $\triangle ABC$ onto $\triangle A'B'C'$.



[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle ABC and triangle A prime B prime C prime are drawn. Triangle ABC has point A at seven, six, point B at five, five, and point C at four, three. Triangle A prime, B prime, C prime has point A prime at negative one, six, point B prime at one, five, point C prime at two, three. There is a point three, five and point three, three with a vertical line passing through both points.

hints.content: We are given the scale $\purple{1}\text{ unit}=\pink{\dfrac{1}{2}}\text{ mm}$. Multiplying the scale by $2$, an equivalent scale would be $\purple{2}\text{ units}=\pink1\text{ mm}$.
Using the scale $\purple{2}\text{ units}=\pink{1}\text{ mm}$, let's  convert ${9}\text{ mm}$ to units.

$\qquad\begin{align} &{9}\cancel{\text{mm}}\cdot\dfrac{\purple2\text{ units}}{\pink1\cancel{\text{mm}}}\\
&= \blue{18}\text{ units} \end{align}$

Move the points on the square to create the scale drawing.


[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: A quadrilateral with all sides of equal length labelled as 18 units each. The vertices are marked with filled dots and the sides are at right angles with each other.

Draw $\tealD{\dfrac{5}{4}}$.

[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: Two fraction models with each large square representing 1 whole. The first fraction has 40 out of 40 equal parts shaded.  The second fraction model has 4 parts. 1 part is partitioned into 10 equal parts and are shaded.

hints.content:
Each of the $\goldD{10}$ rows is $\dfrac{5}{40}$ of a whole.

[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: Two fraction models with each large square representing 1 whole. The first fraction has 40 out of 40 equal parts shaded. 4 parts are shaded darker. The second fraction has 10 out of 40 equal parts shaded. 1 part is shaded darker.

hints.content: We can also use the image to see that $\tealD{\dfrac{5}{4}} \div \goldD{10}$ is the same as $\dfrac{1}{\goldD{10}} \text{ of }\tealD{ \dfrac{5}{4}}$.
$\dfrac{1}\goldD{10} \text{ of } \tealD{\dfrac{5}{4}} = \dfrac{1}\goldD{10} \times \tealD{\dfrac{5}{4}}$
$\dfrac{1}\goldD{10} \times \tealD{\dfrac{5}{4}}=$ $\dfrac{1\times\tealD{5}}{\goldD{10}\times\tealD4}=\dfrac{5}{40}$

$\dfrac{5}{4} \div 10 = \dfrac{5}{40}$

[[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Yes!  We can simplify $\dfrac5{40}$ by dividing the numerator and denominator by $5$.

$\dfrac{5}{40}=\dfrac{5\div5}{40\div5}=\dfrac1{8}$

So, in simplest form, $\dfrac{5}{4} \div 10 = \dfrac{5}{40}=\dfrac{1}{8}$.

(54Ã·10)=(54Ã—110)=54Ã—10=540=18

analysisNotes: not all of the answer inputs are correct even though mathematically they should be. Instead of allowing users to generate their own questions, let's create a dropdown of 4 equation with one correct one

hints.content: Gustave walked $\maroonD{6300}$ steps, which was the same as  $\blueD3$ miles. We are calling the number of steps in one mile for Gustave $\green{s}$.

We can represent the total number of steps Gustave took on his walk as a product:

$\blueD{3} \greenD{s}$

We know that there were a total of  $\maroonD{6300}$ steps.

We can set these two expressions equal to describe this situation with an equation:

$\blueD{3} \greenD{s} = \maroonD{6300}$

Other ways to represent the situation with an equation include: $\dfrac{\maroonD{6300}}{\greenD s}=\blueD3$ or $\dfrac{\maroonD{6300}}{\blueD 3}=\greenD s$.

The following equation matches this situation:


$3s=6300$

There are $2100$ steps in one mile for Gustave.

question.content:
[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

Gustave measured his pace and determined that for him, $s$ steps make up one mile. One day Gustave walked $6300$ steps, which was $3$ miles. 

**Write an equation to describe this situation.** 

[[â˜ƒ expression 1]]

**How many steps are in one mile for Gustave?**

[[â˜ƒ numeric-input 1]]

. From this, the number of steps in one mile is
Not quite. Use the relationship between steps and miles: the total steps for the walk equals the number of miles times the steps per mile.

xmlData:
3s=6300 6300=3s 3s = 6300 6300 = 3s 2100 0

Gustave measured his pace and determined that for him, s steps make up one mile. One day Gustave walked 6300 steps, which was 3 miles.

Write an equation to describe this situation.

How many steps are in one mile for Gustave?

Correct! One equation that represents the situation is 3s=6300. From this, the number of steps in one mile is 2100.

Not quite. Use the relationship between steps and miles: the total steps for the walk equals the number of miles times the steps per mile.

An appropriate equation is 3s=6300, and dividing both sides by 3 gives s=2100.

hints.content:
If the **constant of proportionality** is $\greenD{2}$, then:

$\maroonD{y}=\greenD{2}\blueD{x}$

Which table follows that pattern?

$x$ | $y$ | $\greenD{2}x$
- | - | -
$2$ | $5$ | $2\cdot 2=4$
$6$ | $15$ | $2\cdot 6=12$
$12$ | $30$ | $2\cdot 12=24$

This table does not follow the pattern.

$x$ | $y$ | $\greenD{2}x$
- | - | -
$3$ | $6$ | $2\cdot 3=6$
$5$ | $10$ | $2\cdot 5=10$
$18$ | $36$ | $2\cdot 18=36$

This table follows the pattern.

$x$ | $y$ | $\greenD{2}x$
- | - | -
$6$ | $24$ | $2\cdot 6=12$
$10$ | $40$ | $2\cdot 10=20$
$14$ | $56$ | $2\cdot 14=28$

This table does not follow the pattern.

This is the table that shows a constant of proportionality of $2$ between $y$ and $x$.

$x$ | $y$ 
- | - 
$3$ | $6$
$5$ | $10$
$18$ | $36$

x | y - | - 2 | 5 6 | 15 12 | 30

Not quite. A constant of proportionality of 2 means multiply x by 2 to get y for every row of the table.

hints.content: Let $x$ equal the decimal. Set up two equations such that the digits after the decimal point are identical.

Subtracting the two equations, we have:

 $\large{9x = 24}$
$\large{ x = \dfrac{24}{9}} $
$ \large{x = \dfrac{8}{3}} \quad \text{or} \quad\large{2 \dfrac{2}{3}} $

content.content: Subtract the original equation from this result:

8/3 0

2.6â€¾

Not quite. Let x=2.6â€¾. Then multiply both sides by 10 to align the repeating digits.

10x=26.6â€¾

Subtract the original equation from this result:

10x-x=26.6â€¾-2.6â€¾=24

9x=24, so x=249=83

hints.content: $ \dfrac{33}{25}$ represents $33 \div 25 $.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\phantom{0.00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33\phantom{.00}}\\
\end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\phantom{0.00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)\blue{3}3\phantom{.00}}\\
\end{array}$

How many times does $25$ go into $\blue{3}$?

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\green{0}\phantom{0.00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)\blue{3}3\phantom{.00}}\\
\end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr}
&0\phantom{0.00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)\blue{33}\phantom{.00}}\\
\end{array}$

How many times does $25$ go into $\blue{33}$?

$\begin{array}{rr}
&0\green{1}\phantom{.00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)\blue{33}\phantom{.00}}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&\pink{8\phantom{.00}}
\end{array}$

$\blue{33} \div 25 = \green{1}$ with a remainder of $\pink{8}$.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.\phantom{00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.0\phantom{0}}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&8\phantom{.00}
\end{array}$

Write a decimal point and a $0$ in the tenths place.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.\phantom{00}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.0\phantom0}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.}{\downarrow}\phantom{0}\\
&\blue{8\phantom{.}0\phantom{0}}
\end{array}$

How many times does $25$ go into $\blue{80}$?

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.\green{3}\phantom{0}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.0\phantom{0}}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&\blue{8\phantom{.}0}\phantom{0}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{7\phantom{.}5}\phantom{0}\\
&\pink{5}\phantom{0}
\end{array}$

$\blue{80} \div 25 = \green{3}$ with a remainder of $\pink{5}$.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.3\phantom{0}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.00}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&8\phantom{.}0\phantom{0}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{7\phantom{.}5}\phantom{0}\\
&5\phantom{0}
\end{array}$

Write a $0$ in the hundredths place.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.3\phantom0&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.00}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.0}{\downarrow}\\
&8\phantom{.}0{\downarrow}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{7\phantom{.}5}{\downarrow}\\
&\blue{50}
\end{array}$

How many times does $25$ go into $\blue{50}$?

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.3\green{2}&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.00}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&8\phantom{.}0\phantom{0}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{7\phantom{.}5}\phantom{0}\\
&\blue{50}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{50}\\
&\pink{0}
\end{array}$

$\blue{50} \div 25 = \green{2}$ with a remainder of $\pink{0}$.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&01.32&\\
{25}&\overline{\Big)33.00}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{25}\phantom{.00}\\
&8\phantom{.}0\phantom{0}\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{7\phantom{.}5}\phantom{0}\\
&50\\
&\mathllap{-}\underline{50}\\
&0
\end{array}$

The remainder is $0$, so we have our answer.

analysisNotes: The diagram is somewhat difficult to read due to the "20 cm" label being placed in a position where many lines overlap it. The "20 cm" label should be placed to the right of the bottom right edge of the diagram (i.e., the rectangular prism's bottom surface' right line segment) to be properly viewable.

hints.content: The juice box is a rectangular prism. We can find the volume of a rectangular prism if we know its length, width, and height.

$\begin{align} \text{Volume of the juice box} &= \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\cdot \text{height}\\\\
&= 20 \cdot 10 \frac12 \cdot 30 \\\\
&= 20 \cdot 30 \cdot 10 \frac12\\\\
&= 600 \cdot 10 \frac12 \\\\
&= 600 \cdot 10.5 \\\\
&= \blueD{6300} \\\\
\end{align}$

The juice box has a volume of $\blueD{6300} \text{ cm}^3$.

$\begin{align} \text{Days Bruce has juice for} &= \dfrac{\text{Total volume of juice box}}{\text{Volume Bruce drinks each day}}  \\\\
&= \dfrac{\blueD{6300}}{630} \\\\
&= 10 \\\\
\end{align}$
The answer is $10$ days.

Bruce bought the enormous box of juice shown below. Each day he plans to drink 630 cubic centimeters of juice.

How many days will it take Bruce to drink the box of juice?

Select one answer.

1 day

4 days

7 days

10 days

Correct! It will take 10 days.

The box is a rectangular prism, so its volume is length Ã— width Ã— height: Volume=20Ã—1012Ã—30=600Ã—10.5=6300 cubic centimeters. Dividing by the daily amount gives 6300630=10 days.

Then divide the total volume by the amount Bruce drinks each day: days=total volume630 cubic centimeters per day.

analysisNotes: Importantly, the correct answers of "25Ï€" or "78.5" are marked as incorrect upon submission. The question can be somewhat misleading due to the presence of the entire circle shape, rather than just the quarter-circle that the question is in reference to.

hints.content:
###Getting started

We want to find the area of $\dfrac14$ of a circle. Let's start by finding the area of the full circle.

###Step 1: Find the area of the full circle


$\begin{align}\text{Area of the circle} &=  \pi r^2\\\\  &= \pi 10^2 \\\\
&= \blueD{100\pi} \\\\
\end{align}$

### Step 2: Find the area of $\dfrac14$ of the circle

$\begin{align} \text{Area of } \dfrac14 \text{ of the circle} &=  \dfrac14 \cdot \blueD{100\pi} \\\\
  &= \dfrac{100}4 \pi \\\\
&= 25\pi \\\\
\end{align}$

###The answer

The area of the shape is $25\pi$ units$^2$.

*(Note that we could also multiply $25$ by $3.14$ to get $78.5$ units$^2$.)*

The degree label "54" could be farther away from its associated point (i.e., point "B") in order to prevent overlap with the angle arc line.

hints.content:
The interior angles of a triangle always add up to $180^\circ$.

$\begin{align}\greenD{\angle ABC} + \purpleD{\angle BAC} +\maroonD{\angle BCA} &= 180^\circ
\\\\
\greenD{54^\circ}+\purpleD{105^\circ} + \maroonD{\angle BCA}&= 180^\circ
 \\\\
\maroonD{\angle BCA} &= 21^\circ \end{align}$



[[â˜ƒ image 1]]

options.alt: Two parallel lines labeled line BC and line DE.  Line FC intersects the parallel lines at point A and C.  Line segment AB connects the parallel lines.  Points B and D are on the same side of line FC. Angle ABC is 54 degrees.  Angle BAC is 105 degrees. Angle BCA is 21 degrees. Angle DAF is x degrees.

hints.content:
Since $\overline{BC}$ is parallel to $\overline{DE}$, $\maroonD{\angle BCA}$ and $ \blueD{\angle{DAF}}$ are corresponding angles, so they are congruent.

$\blueD{\angle DAF}$ is the same as $\blueD{\angle x}.$

So  $\maroonD{\angle BCA}$ and $ \blueD{\angle{x}}$ $ = \blueD{21^\circ}$.

hints.content:
On a horizontal number line: 

* Numbers to the right are greater than numbers to the left.
* Numbers to the left are less than numbers to the right.
$\purpleD{-\dfrac{2}{3}}$ is located to the *right* of $\maroonD{-\dfrac{5}{2}}$, so it is *greater than* $\maroonD{-\dfrac{5}{2}}$.

On the number line, $\purpleD{-\dfrac{2}{3}}$ is to the right of $\maroonD{-\dfrac{5}{2}}$.

This means $\purpleD{-\dfrac{2}{3}}$ is greater than $\maroonD{-\dfrac{5}{2}}$.
